title: Latest version no longer completely loads hints in familysearch.org and it takes a very long time to get a partial pane started.
content: Just upgraded one computer to Firefox v143.0.1 and now familysearch.org is very slow and will not load hints. v142.0.1 is still on my other computer and familysearch.org works normally. Within familysearch, I can click on a hint and a pane opens on the right. It normally populates within a second or two at most. With v143.0.1, it takes a minute to partially populate, then it goes no further. With v142.0.1 it works normally. I've disabled add-ons. Cleared cache. Deleted TEMP files. Restarted browser. Restarted computer. Nothing has worked. Previous upgrades over the years have not had this issue. Other browsers (Chrome, Vivaldi, Brave, Edge, SeaMonkey) do not have this issue. Attaching a picture of this page: https://www.familysearch.org/en/tree/person/details/G4QP-T3S A free familysearch account is required to see it--only an e-mail address is required. The right pane has been trying to load for over 4 hours at this point. Normally takes about 2 seconds.
creator: sstebleton

title: Letâ€™s Retire the Word â€œChatbotâ€â€”Itâ€™s Time for Firefox to Call LLMs What They Are!
content:
Hi Firefox community,

Iâ€™m not your usual tech influencer or a corporate â€œenthusiastâ€â€”Iâ€™m just a longtime open source user whoâ€™s spent more than a few years behind the veiled curtain, watching how this world of software and possibility unfolds. I love what Mozilla does for users like me. Thatâ€™s exactly why I want to raise something: I keep seeing the word â€œchatbotâ€ show up for Firefoxâ€™s new AI-powered assistants (like the sidebar and whatâ€™s coming next). But letâ€™s be honestâ€”â€œchatbotâ€ belongs to the days of robotic customer service and scripted dead-ends.

What we have now in Firefoxâ€”powered by real LLMs (Large Language Models)â€”is a whole different species. Calling these assistants â€œchatbotsâ€ just doesnâ€™t fit. It sells short what LLM-based assistants can do: theyâ€™re powerful, context-aware, and, at times, strikingly human in their conversation. New users might miss the true magic if we stick to old language. So why not call them â€œAI assistants,â€ â€œLLM-powered assistants,â€ or just â€œAIâ€ instead? It would help everyone see the progress, and show how Mozillaâ€™s still leading, not just catching up.

Iâ€™ll leave it open for discussion, but I hope others feel this shift too. Language shapes how we see these thingsâ€”and sometimes it takes a Singular Fella (or maybe two) to nudge the world past old memes. Thanks for hearing me out, and hereâ€™s to a future where our assistants, and our words, keep getting smarter.

â€”Robert Beck

title: [SOLVED] Stop Firefox suggestion pop-ups
content:
Firefox has started giving me suggestions via pop ups. Please would someone tell me how to turn off Firefox suggestions?

This is a pet hate of mine. MS suggests games for me to play, and Google suggests that I sign in with a Google account. Now Firefox is suggesting things. Noooo!

I found it at the bottom of three lines> settings. Uncheck: Recommend extensions as you browse Learn more Recommend features as you browse Learn more

This may be a new feature. There are no Google hits for the suggestion wording "keep your email in your taskbar" so I take the liberty of posting this here.

Tim
